cards.title: Frank O'Connor award / 'Truly original' stories of Carys Davies win
cards.rawTitle: 'Truly original' stories of Carys Davies win

item.title: Frank O’Connor award won by 'truly original' stories of Carys Davies
item.trailText: The Redemption of Galen Pike takes €25,000 prize for the year’s best short story collection
item.standFirst: The Redemption of Galen Pike takes €25,000 prize for the year’s best short story collection
item.body:
The Welsh author Carys Davies has won the Frank O’Connor international short story award for her second collection, The Redemption of Galen Pike.

The €25,000 (£18,000) prize, the world’s most lucrative for a single collection of short stories, has been won in the past by some of the genre’s biggest names, including Haruki Murakami and Edna O’Brien. Davies, who now lives in Lancaster, beat writers including the American authors Karen E Bender and Tony Earley, and the British writer Kirsty Gunn, to win this year’s prize.

Her collection, The Redemption of Galen Pike, is published by the small UK independent press Salt. Its subjects span the world, with stories set everywhere from a remote Australian settlement, where a young wife has a secret, to a Colorado jail, where a Quaker woman meets a condemned man in his final hours in the title story.

“Galen Pike’s crime revolted Patience more than she could say, and on her way to the jailhouse to meet him for the first time, she told herself she wouldn’t think of it; walking past the closed bank, the shuttered front of the general store, the locked-up haberdasher’s, the drawn blinds of the dentist, she averted her gaze,” writes Davies. “She would do what she always did with the felons; she would bring Galen Pike something to eat and drink, she would sit with him and talk to him and keep him company in the days that he had left.”

The Irish novelist Éibhear Walshe, part of the judging panel for this year’s prize, called it “a truly original and striking collection, full of funny, keenly observed stories replete with twists and turns that surprise”.

Davies, Walshe said, was a “remarkable voice”, adding: “The language is economical with not a word to spare. Davies takes historical moments and themes and examines them in novel ways which intrigue the reader.”

The author pronounced herself “delighted, grateful, and completely astonished” to win the prize, which is sponsored by Cork city council and by the school of English, University College Cork.

Patrick Cotter, award director, praised Davies as a “gifted writer”, and her press Salt as “a small independent, gritty publisher which has been dedicated to the short story for over a decade, often publishing more short story titles in a year than the imprints of major international conglomerates”.

cards.title: Star Wars spin-off / Should Aaron Paul play Han Solo?
cards.rawTitle: Should Aaron Paul play Han Solo?

item.title: Star Wars spin-off: should Aaron Paul play Han Solo – and what about the plot?
item.trailText: Should the younger take on the iconic space smuggler be fresh-faced or early-stage world-weary? How did he meet Chewie and why did he fall out with Jabba? Five key questions for the directors of the new Star Wars spin-off
item.standFirst: Should the younger take on the iconic space smuggler be fresh-faced or early-stage world-weary? How did he meet Chewie and why did he fall out with Jabba? Five key questions for the directors of the new Star Wars spin-off
item.body:
Related: The Lego Movie writer/directors: ‘We wanted to make an anti-totalitarian movie for kids'

You wait a month for more Star Wars spin-off movie news to be announced and then two bombshells come along at once. First: Darth Vader might be set to return in Gareth Edwards’s Rogue One. And second: Lego Movie writer-directors Christopher Miller and Phil Lord are to take on the long-mooted Han Solo movie.

Of all the films set within the wider Star Wars universe which Disney-owned Lucasfilm is now developing, this one looks the most exciting – and the most high stakes. Here are five key questions Miller and Lord need to answer before the cameras roll.

How old should Solo be, and who should play him?

Related: Mad Max’s Nicholas Hoult on hanging off lorries and channeling Andrex puppies

Reports suggest that Lord and Miller’s take will be an origins story, and Star Wars lore reckons Solo was around 29 during the events of the first movie, so it’s perhaps unsurprising that Hollywood sites have been pushing young twentysomethings such as Taron Egerton (25), Ansel Elgort (21) and Nicholas Hoult (25) for the role of the iconic space smuggler. Yet Ford himself was 33 when he began filming Star Wars, his seniority over Mark Hamill (Luke Skywalker) and Carrie Fisher (Princess Leia) giving Solo an essential wily world-weariness. And there’s something about the idea of a fresh-faced take on the Corellian scoundrel that jars.

If Disney-owned Lucasfilm is looking to ape the success of Marvel with its plan for a Star Wars cinematic universe, it should bear in mind that its sister studio has generally plumped for seasoned actors over callow ingenues when casting iconic heroes. Picking an act in their early 30s, perhaps playing a few years younger, would allow Solo to retain just enough of his “been around the block” swagger to keep him recognisable to fans. If Aaron Paul (35 and bookies’ favourite), Taylor Kitsch (34) and Chris Pratt (36) are just too old for the role – well they’d still make better choices than those previously mentioned. Paul, at least, seems more than keen, and someone at Star Wars – even if it’s just the social media editor – is evidently interested.

Then again, the American actor just doesn’t look like a Han Solo type to me, though perhaps I’m being swayed by hours of watching him as a whiny meth addict in Breaking Bad. Second-favourite Aaron Taylor-Johnson has the right mix of brawn and swagger, and is capable of playing older than his 25 years.

How did Han and Chewbacca meet?

Related: Behind the scenes of Star Wars – in pictures

Since the Wookiee co-pilot of the Millennium Falcon is more than 200 years old during the events of the original trilogy, it stands to reason that he and Solo were not always friends. Expanded-universe novels about the smuggler suggest he met his eventual sidekick while working as a pilot on an Imperial slave ship. After he refuses orders to flay the wookiee, Solo and his new pal escape with the help of rebels and the hairy eight-foot-tall humanoid swears a life debt to his saviour. Disney is highly unlikely to borrow too much from the non-canonical books, but Lord and Miller will surely take the chance to bring back one of the saga’s best-known heroes, and explain why he displays such selfless loyalty to Solo. See also: How did Han meet Lando Calrissian and successfully prise the Falcon from his old pal’s possession.

Why does Solo hate the Force?

Han displays a determined scorn for Jedi-like behaviour in the events of the original trilogy. Again, the expanded universe has an answer here, suggesting that the young Solo was once the victim of a religious fraud which left him a distinct non-believer in regard to spiritual matters. The smart route for Lord and Miller would be to avoid delving too deep into such matters: it’s enough for us to know that the Jedi were almost extinct at the beginning of 1977’s Star Wars, so it would hardly be rare for more cynical citizens of the galaxy to view their supposed powers as the stuff of myth and legend. We do, however, need to know how Solo became so world-weary in the first place.

How did Han upset Jabba the Hutt?

George Lucas’s decision to include a CGI version of the corpulent alien in the 1997 special edition of Star Wars will always go down as one of the most misguided film-making decisions ever to rear its ugly head in Hollywood. And Miller and Lord will presumably think carefully before introducing their own youthful, perambulatory version of the iconic gangster. Nevertheless, we know from the original movies that Solo owes a large debt to Jabba that he is either unwilling or unable to pay before being captured by Darth Vader’s forces in Cloud City and transported to the repugnant alien’s Tatooinese lair. Surely the origins of this storyline will play some part in the new film.

Did Han really make the Kessel Run in 12 parsecs, and what does that even mean?

Related: Star Wars: The Force Awakens trailer – a return to the series' strengths

Solo’s boast at the beginning of 1977’s Star Wars can be read in a number of ways. Since a parsec is a unit of distance, rather than time, the smuggler may simply have been talking a load of nonsense in order to secure the patronage of Obi-Wan Kenobi and Luke Skywalker for their trip to Alderaan. George Lucas has said the apparent paradox of a ship covering an 18 parsec route without travelling the full distance can be explained by the Falcon’s advanced navigational computer rather than its engines, which allow it to calculate a smarter route. The expanded universe picks up on the anomaly, suggesting the route itself skirted a cluster of black holes, with Solo managing to cut down his travel time by flying dangerously close to the cosmic bodies. Now wouldn’t that make a scene to rival Han’s romp through the Hoth asteroid field in The Empire Strikes Back?

cards.title: Shaggy’s right – pop really is our best weapon in the war against terror
cards.rawTitle: Shaggy’s right – pop really is our best weapon in the war against terror

item.title: Shaggy’s right – pop really is our best weapon in the war against terror
item.trailText: If the reggae star’s music-and-marijuana plan can stop young people joining Islamic State, think what he could achieve with H from Steps by his side
item.standFirst: If the reggae star’s music-and-marijuana plan can stop young people joining Islamic State, think what he could achieve with H from Steps by his side
item.body:
Reggae and weed, weed and reggae – that’s the strategy to defeat Islamic State, according to the reggae star Shaggy.

“If they’re listening to Shaggy music or reggae music, they’re not going to want to cut somebody’s head off,” Shaggy told the Miami New Times this week. “There’re two thing [sic] you want to do when you listen to reggae: You get somebody pregnant, or you’re fucking high. High people don’t want to kill nothing; they want to love. They need to bag some Jamaican weed and distribute it amongst Isis. I guarantee there won’t be any more wars out there.”

Related: Shaggy: Islamic State would pack it in if they listened to reggae and got high

What Shaggy is essentially suggesting here is that we blast It Wasn’t Me out of repurposed attack helicopters and drop little baggies of marijuana over Syria and then boom: war is over. Truly, he is this generation’s John Lennon.

Say what you want about the idea – that it’s stupid, that it’s unworkable, that it hints at a mind corrupted and rendered unusable by the sheer perplexity of being famous in the early-to-mid noughties, at an ego ruined by two decades of people shouting “MR LOVER-LOVER, A-LOVER, MMM” back at him in the street – but at least Shaggy’s doing something. What have you ever done to combat possibly the greatest terror of our time? I bet the answer is: nothing.

No idea is a bad idea when we’re brainstorming counter-terrorism. Because it’s not like pop artists don’t have form for attempting to solve tricky international problems with their singing-and-dancing expertise. Look at Geldof, with his angry demands for money. Wyclef Jean’s doomed 2010 Haitian presidential bid. Chris Martin doing that thing where he draws on his hands. Geri Halliwell inexplicably being appointed UN Population Fund representative back in 1999. Bez trying to be an MP. If history has taught us anything, it’s that the only real chance for peace and tranquillity in our time is to wrench power away from the suits and give it to our pop stars.

To that end, I think it’s time more of our pop idols did a Shaggy, and mucked in to rid the world of despair and general menace. Because if just one teenager listens to Shaggy and decides, “Actually, maybe I won’t join Isis after all. Maybe I’ll sing catchy pop songs about being caught in flagrante on, of all places, a bathroom floor, the place statistically most likely to have piss on it in the whole house” – it will not have been in vain.

I’d like to see more pop stars getting on board with Shaggy’s anti-Isis message, getting a bit more proactive. You feel that both Adele and Pitbull would be exceptionally handy in a fight: why have they not been airlifted in to kick seven shades out of Isis in a Syrian alleyway? Jessie J can use her piercing vocal range as a noise weapon, with very little tweaking to her current musical output. Get Rita Ora over there, if only to get her away from us. Send H from Steps in there as part of some sort of peacekeeping envoy.

Both Adele and Pitbull would be handy in a fight: why haven't they been airlifted in to kick seven shades out of Isis?

Can you imagine being mad enough to start a holy war with H from Steps cheerfully lilting to you about how he and Claire were the real talent in the band? You cannot. You’ve got a rocket launcher in your hand, aimed at the clear blue sky. The sound of helicopters in the distance, hatred in your heart. “Lisa was essentially just a trumped-up dancer,” H from Steps whispers. You put your weapons down.

Sam Smith, no bandwagon too desperate for him to slide on to, gently and fragilely performs Stay With Me in the middle of a warzone, soldiers from both sides too confused by the fact that his haircut is consistently just a little bit too narrow for his skull to bother firing their weapons any more. And lo, once more pop has saved the day.

Music is powerful and pop stars are the conduit for it. Can people get pregnant without reggae? They cannot. Can they get high on Jamaican weed without music? Also no. Can it stop wars? If Shaggy has anything to say about it, yes it can. Thank you, Shaggy, your plan is watertight. Truly, the west is blessed to have you.

cards.title: Piers Morgan / From roaring 20s to roaring 50s

item.title: Piers Morgan: from roaring 20s to roaring 50s
item.trailText: Former CNN presenter and Daily Mirror editor celebrates his half century in typically understated style with a Great Gatsby-themed party
item.standFirst: Former CNN presenter and Daily Mirror editor celebrates his half century in typically understated style with a Great Gatsby-themed party
item.body:
Piers Morgan isn’t exactly known for being the shy, retiring type – so a Great Gatsby-themed 50th birthday party seems entirely in character.

Synchronised swimmers, Folies Bergere-style dance troupe, boaters, white suits and more than few celebs joined Morgan at his house on Sunday. Lord Sugar was there (he made a speech), as was Susanna Reid, Charlotte Hawkins, Kate Garraway, Myleene Klass and Amanda Holden.

Also in attendance were Financial Times editor Lionel Barber, journalist and author Tony Parsons, Morgan’s successor at the helm of the Mirror, Richard Wallace, and Matt Kelly of Local World.

Related: Piers Morgan criticised for laughing as Good Morning Britain guest swore on air

Morgan snapped Anthony McPartlin of Ant and Dec fame trying to skim a golf ball across the swimming pool.

And of course no prizes for guessing which character Morgan played. Though swap that suit for a bathrobe and he’d look more comfortable in the Playboy mansion.

cards.title: YouTube / PewDiePie responds to 'haters' over £4.8m earnings

item.title: YouTube star PewDiePie responds to 'haters' over $7.4m annual earnings
item.trailText: ‘It seems like the whole world cares more about how much money I make than I do myself,’ says online gaming star in video posted for fans
item.standFirst: ‘It seems like the whole world cares more about how much money I make than I do myself,’ says online gaming star in video posted for fans
item.body:
YouTube star Felix ‘PewDiePie’ Kjellberg has responded to online criticism after it was revealed that he earned $7.4m in 2014 from his gaming videos.

The earnings were published in a financial filing in Sweden by his company PewDie Productions and reported on news site Expressen.

Related: YouTube: PewDiePie, DC Toys Collector and Katy Perry top in 2014

The PewDiePie channel was the most popular on YouTube in 2014 with more than 4bn video views, ending the year with more than 33 million subscribers.

As news stories about Kjellberg’s income trended on Facebook, though, he was attacked for not deserving these financial rewards, spurring him into publishing a YouTube video called “Let’s Talk About Money” to address the criticism.

“Money is a topic that I have purposefully tried to avoid for the five years that I’ve been making videos, because I just feel like it’s not important to anyone,” said the 25-year-old, before reminding fans that he funded his early efforts on YouTube by working on a hot-dog stand.

“The fact that I could make videos was so much more important to me than [that] I had to spend a few hours a day doing a job that wasn’t that prestigious,” he said.

“I knew people were big at other types of videos, but there was no one big in gaming, and I didn’t know you could make money out of it. It was never like a career that I could just quit college to pursue. it was just something I loved to do. And here we are five years later and it’s exploded.”

Kjellberg read out and responded to some of the more critical Facebook comments during his video, while defending the work he puts in to his channel, which focuses on “Let’s Play” videos playing through games while commentating on them.

“A lot of people which I saw were very very angry. They thought it was unfair. They thought I just sit on my ass all day, and I just yell at the screen over here. Which is true! But there’s so much more to it than that,” he said.

“I understand that haters are gonna hate, alright? But I really think that money doesn’t make you happy. I am just as happy as I am now, as I was five years ago ... To see so many people being upset about this whole thing, it’s sad. It’s such a waste.”

Kjellberg also expressed irritation that his charitable fundraising attracts less coverage than his earnings, having raised money for the likes of Save the Children and Charity:Water, as his popularity has grown on YouTube.

Related: YouTube star PewDiePie strikes publishing deal for This Book Loves You

“It seems like the whole world cares more about how much money I make than I do myself. We did raise a million dollars for charity, and very few articles picked up on that, but here it is everywhere how much money I make,” he said.

“I don’t think there’s any good reason why anyone should care, and on top of that I don’t think there’s any good reason why I should care either, so we’re just going to end it there.”

One good reason people care within the media world is that PewDiePie’s financial filing offers a rare insight into the money being made at the top end of YouTube stardom.

It’s very rare for any YouTube creator to talk about their earnings publicly, not least because YouTube itself does not encourage it.

But with many of its top stars essentially freelancers – even if they’re signed to a multi-channel network, as Kjellberg is to Maker Studios – those with their own companies will increasingly be declaring their income in financial filings.

cards.title: Michael Douglas / American male actors are too 'asexual' to get film roles
cards.rawTitle: American male actors are too 'asexual' to get film roles

item.title: Michael Douglas: American male actors are too 'asexual' to get film roles
item.trailText: Veteran says that there are too many ‘sensitive young men’ in US film, allowing more macho and better trained Australian and British actors to take meaty roles
item.standFirst: Veteran says that there are too many ‘sensitive young men’ in US film, allowing more macho and better trained Australian and British actors to take meaty roles
item.body:
Related: Dustin Hoffman: film is the worst it has ever been

Days after Dustin Hoffman said that films had never been worse than they are today, fellow actor Michael Douglas has spoken out about what he believes to be “a crisis in young American actors right now”. The actor said they are overly concerned about their image and lack machismo.

“Everyone’s much more image conscious than they are about actually playing the part,” Douglas said in an interview with the Independent. According to the two-time Oscar winner, an American obsession with image and social media has enabled international actors to take many of the top American roles away from US male actors.

“Clearly, it breaks down on two fronts,” he said. “In Britain they take their training seriously while in the States, we’re going through a sort of social media image-conscious thing rather than formal training. Many actors are getting caught up in this image thing which is going on to affect their range.”

Douglas added that Australian male actors are favoured over US talent for their masculinity. “In the US we have this relatively asexual or unisex area with sensitive young men and we don’t have many Channing Tatums or Chris Pratts, while the Aussies do,” he said. “It’s a phenomena.”

This doesn’t mark the first time that Douglas has spoken about his concern for the current generation of young American male actors. In a February interview with Entertainment Weekly, the actor addressed the “crisis”.

“The issue I hear from casting agents is that young American actors now are very self-conscious of their image,” he said. “So rather than playing truthful and themselves – it might be because of so much cable, so much stuff on the internet – they’re almost kind of capturing an image of what they think they should be, rather than playing it.”

cards.title: Mr Burns returns / Harry Shearer 'to stay on The Simpsons'
cards.rawTitle: Harry Shearer 'to stay on The Simpsons'

item.title: Mr Burns returns: Harry Shearer 'to stay on The Simpsons for $300,000 a show'
item.trailText: Shearer, who also voices Ned Flanders and Principal Skinner, has reportedly reversed decision to quit and signed deal that will keep core cast together
item.standFirst: Shearer, who also voices Ned Flanders and Principal Skinner, has reportedly reversed decision to quit and signed deal that will keep core cast together
item.body:
Fans of The Simpsons can breathe a sigh of relief as reports suggest Harry Shearer, voice of Mr Burns and many other much-loved characters, has reversed his decision to leave the long-running show.

Shearer had tweeted in May that he would no longer feature, apparently following a dispute with producers. Showrunner Al Jean told the New York Times that Shearer “was offered the same deal the rest of the cast accepted, and passed”, with the voice actor indicating the impasse related to his freedom to do other work and was not related to pay.

Related: Was Sam Simon-era Simpsons the show's golden age?

But Shearer has reportedly signed a four-season contract which will keep the main Simpsons cast together, according to Entertainment Weekly. It said the deal is worth $300,000 (£194,000) per episode for stars Shearer, Dan Castellaneta, Yeardley Smith, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, and Hank Azaria.

It means characters including Ned Flanders, Principal Skinner, Kent Brockman and Waylon Smithers – all voiced by Shearer – will continue to feature in new episodes. The show, first screened in 1989, has recently been renewed by Fox for a 27th and 28th season, which would take its tally of episodes well above 600.

After Shearer suggested he was leaving because of inflexible schedules, Jean tweeted saying that it was “confusing” that Shearer implied he left to do other projects, “which we always let him do”.

“Everybody on the show does lots of outside projects. He actually gets to record on the phone and do the [table] reads on the phone. So we’ve never kept him from doing that stuff,” Jean told Entertainment Weekly in May.

But the door was left open for Shearer to return, and he tweeted later that month that “discussions are happening at a level where decisions can be made”. If Shearer had not been persuaded to re-sign, Simpsons producers said that his much-loved characters would not be killed off, but would be recast with new voice actors.

Shearer has enjoyed a varied career outside of The Simpsons. He co-wrote and starred in rock mockumentary Spinal Tap prior to joining the show, and last year played Richard Nixon in TV series Nixon’s The One, in which he acted out White House recordings of the former president.
